content.description:
Fictional characters deal with feelings of guilt in different ways. Some shrug off guilt with apparent ease, while others suffer more from guilt than they do from external consequences imposed on them for their actions.

Either from your own reading or from the list below, choose a work of fiction in which a character changes—or remains unchanged—as a result of guilt. Then, in a well-written essay, analyze how that character’s response contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole. Do not merely summarize the plot.

In your response you should do the following:

Respond to the prompt with a thesis that presents an interpretation and may establish a line of reasoning.

Select and use evidence to develop and support your line of reasoning.

Explain the relationship between the evidence and your thesis.

Use appropriate grammar and punctuation in communicating your argument.

Adam Bede

Adventures of Huckleberry Finn

All the King’s Men

All the Light We Cannot See

The Aspern Papers

Atonement

Beloved

Brave New World

The Catcher in the Rye

The Color Purple

Death Comes for the Archbishop

Death of a Salesman

East of Eden

Ethan Frome

Fences

Frankenstein

A Gesture Life

Ghosts

Giovanni’s Room

The God of Small Things

Great Expectations

Hamlet

Invisible Man

Jane Eyre

The Kite Runner

Light in August

Long Day’s Journey Into Night

Lord Jim

Macbeth

Native Son

The Picture of Dorian Gray

Portnoy’s Complaint

The Quiet American

A Raisin in the Sun

The Remains of the Day

Ruth

The Scarlet Letter

A Separate Peace 

The Smell of Apples

The Sound and the Fury

Tess of the D’Urbervilles

The Yellow Birds
content.question: In a well-written essay, analyze how that character’s response contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

skill.text: Skill 1.B: Explain the function of a character changing or remaining unchanged.
